title: Bureau Chief
profile: Richard Williamson is in charge of operations and story assignments in the paper's Dallas bureau, which covers Texas, Colorado and Utah. He accepts pitches for the government/finance beat, which includes the municipal bond market, and the financial planning of legislatures and city councils throughout the three states. He also covers individuals involved in bonds or public finance in the region.     Mr. Williamson is NOT interested in general business stories or any issues that don't directly involve the bond market. He says, "Make sure that you know what the financial angle is and understand our publication [is] narrowly focused." Pitch him by email one week in advance; pictures may be sent as attachments. Urgent pitches may be called in. It is best to reach Mr. Williamson in the morning.

title: Reporter
profile: Jean Louis is a Reporter for the Odessa American. Contact him via email. Jean Louis prefers to receive pitches that cover crime. "However, any pitch that's not crime related, I can always cover it and write a weekender. Weekender stories are typically general assignment reporting, meaning there isn't a specific topic to write about." Attention-catching pitches are ones that are concise and to the point. His advice for PR professionals includes: "Some media specialists aren’t versed at pitching stories that affect the community that the reporter works for. When I read a press release, I like to know why people in my community should care for the story. And if I can't tell why the story is essential to the people I report on, then the pitch isn’t good. Also, if a reporter doesn’t get back to you, as a media specialist, don't give up. Reporters are very busy; just reach out to them again."  His advice on pet peeves: "The biggest problem I had with a media specialist was when he or she sent me a press release that had a fact error. Make sure you double, triple check every fact that you send to me because any error I make during the reporting process can get me in trouble with my editor. If you're the event organizer, you should know every single fact about what's going on. Other than that, everything usually runs smoothly."

title: City Editor
profile: Littlejohn is the City Editor also overseeing the Opinion Page at The Signal in Santa Claritaa, CA. Contact her via e-mail. Littlejohn began serving as the city editor in June 2011. Before that, she served as the city editor for the paper. She has also served as the city editor for the Pasedena (CA) Star-News, for the City News Service of Los Angeles and as an editor for The Associated Press in Los Angeles.   She began her journalism career as a reporter for The Signal. She has taught journalism at the College of the Canyons, Mount San Antonio College and the University of Southern California. She has resided in Canyon Country, CA for over 15 years.
